Key Match Events: Bobby Witt Jr. wanted to take it all in and watch the Yankees celebrate their series victory.
The Royals had a chance to steal Game 1 against Gerrit Cole in New York, losing 6-5.
They had Lugo, an All-Star this season, going in Game 3 and lost by one run, too.

Kyle Isbel put a jolt into a 98 mph fastball with a runner on and the score 3-1 in the bottom of the seventh, but the ball ran out of gas and dropped into the glove of Juan Soto at the base of the wall.
Pre-Game Insights: The Royals' manager, Matt Quatraro, called a meeting in August to emphasize the importance of making changes today and not checking out, worried about the next winter or the next season.
Quatraro kept saying that word, 'Today', and it carried the club through a 15-12 finish last September, through a transformational winter, and through a sneaky-good start in April.
Post-Match Reflections: The Royals' 24-year-old star, Bobby Witt Jr., said that he wanted to sit alone in the dugout, watching the Yankees celebrate on his home field.
Witt said that the mantra 'Today' will survive beyond this year, and the best is yet to come.
The Royals can rue the missed opportunities, but they had a good season and proved that they can play baseball and play at this level.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Royals became just the third team in MLB history to make the playoffs a year after losing 100 games â€” and the first to win a postseason series.
The team had a transformational winter and a sneaky-good start in April, and they put a scare into the Yankees, the top seed in the American League.
Others: The Royals will be back, and they know what they want to be.
Witt said that 'That's reality, that's who we are now.'
